newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil posts $2.031 bln trade deficit Jan/Feb.
newsitem.headline: Brazil posts $2.031 bln trade deficit Jan/Feb.

text.p: Brazil posted a $2.031 billion trade deficit in January and February, the Ministry of Industry and Commerce said.
The ministry said in a statement that exports were $6.831 billion and imports $8.862 billion.
In the same period a year before Brazilian posted a $13 million surplus, the ministry said.
The ministry said that in the two months, average daily exports were $170.8 million, 1.79 percent higher than average daily exports in January/February 1996.
Average daily imports were $221.6 million, 29.9 percent above the same two month period a year ago.
The ministry said that its official deficit figure for February was a shortfall of $2.096 billion, with exports of $3.146 billion and imports of $5.242 billion.
The statement said that oil and lubricant imports in the two months totalled $1.017 billion versus $699 million in the same period in 1996. Of the $1.017 billion, $576 million were gasoline imports.
The ministry said all fuel and lubricant imports not registered in January because of problems with a new Siscomex import registration system were carried over to February official results.

In the two months, raw material imports totalled $4.087 billion against $3.438 billion a year before, capital goods imports were $2.147 billion versus $1.593 billion and imports of consumer goods hit $1.611 billion against $1.135 billion, the ministry said. ((-- Michael Christie, Brasilia newsroom, 5561 2230358))
